Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Comments_List: I learned of the importance of this past century in American history.
Great survey course! I'm a senior history major, so not a lot totally new, but really interesting content from an exceptional instructor.

I am really glad I took the course. I learned some of the broader themes in 20th century American history which is exactly what I wanted to get out of the course. I came to understand how the political parties developed in the past, learned about a lot of different social movements in each era. To think that I lived in this country for ten years without knowing all of these things! I have a much better understanding of how America came to be as I know it today.
Understanding of the major political trends and social movements in the US over the 20th century.

This class is a must-take in my opinion. It filled in a lot of the holes in my understanding of US politics. Professor Gage does a fantastic job of explaining the undercurrents and themes that give rise to and live on following big historical moments.

The course assignments were very conducive to learning how to do archival research, and for that reason I appreciated the assignments. Professor Gage gave very clear lectures that charted the course of 20th century American history. Learned about socialism in the U.S. in early 20th century, roaring 20s volunteerism, New Deal politics and southern democrats, American responses to the depression and WWII, postwar consensus, polarization of the two parties, Reagan, Clinton, Bush.

This class was awesome! I had never really learned about 20th century American history (especially past the 50s) in school before, and it was a clear gap in my knowledge. This course really helped fill in the details about this period and helped me understand how 21st century American came to be. We focused on the changing powers and role of the federal government and the evolution of America's political parties. It was a lot of content that I felt I should have already known, so it was nice to catch up on it! The course's themes were so interesting and relevant. The assignments also allowed me to gain some hands on experience with Yale's resources. Especially the assignment with the Manuscripts and Archives and the one in the stacks. I really felt like I was taking advantage of some classic Yale resources that I had never used before.
I learned a great deal about the 20th century, specifically how certain movements led to others. The flow of the course was very strong.
I learned a lot about 20th Century American history, particularly about the social movements and domestic progress in America at this time.
A broad overview of the political and social change that occurred during the 20th century, as well as analysis of trends throughout the century.

A pretty solid understanding of broad US political movements throughout the course of the 20th century. Professor Gage introduced the class to various historical approaches and did a good job of touching on giving a really strong overview, which was supplemented by a nice selection of mainly primary sources.
American History of the 20th century - quite cool
In this class, I learned some research basics and a general social history of the US in the twentieth century.
I learned a lot about contemporary American history that I had not learned in high school or any of my other Yale history courses.
I developed the ability to analyze primary sources better and to think historically about the present.
I learned a ton about what the previous century was like and why things in the country operate the way they do now.
I learned how to approach history through the study of social movements as well as high politics.
I learned a lot about the history of the American century, learned skills such as using the rare manuscripts and archives, how to adequately use the stacks, and the congressional record.

I gained an incredibly comprehensive dive into the politics and American global affairs of the 20th century, one which was entirely underpinned by the narrative of everyday citizens living in each passing era.
I learned about 20th century American history.
I learned a lot more detailed story of 20th Century American history than I had previously known. It gave me a great context for how politics in America has changed over the past century.

I gained an understanding of the history of the US in the twentieth century. We considered how events connected to each other, and how political change has brought us to our modern day political climate.
I learned so many things about America in the 20th century I don't even know where to start.

I gained an understanding of 20th-century American history, largely focusing on legislative and electoral concerns but with attention as well to social movements and military engagements. This was my first history course at Yale, and the well-designed short writing assignments helped me get a sense of the various research methods that historians use.

I learned so much nuance about American history that I totally missed in high school. I also learned how to effectively write really short papers (which really teaches you how to prioritize!) I also learned about the origins of a lot of movements and their distinctions. I think we have a tendency to throw around "progressive" "conservative" and "liberal", but this classes teaches you the origins of this movements in a way that's really helpful.

Fairly interesting course for someone who had never learned US history.  I learned a lot about political trends, etc. in US 20th century history.  Had I been a beginner I would have learned about source use at Yale, but this class was not my first introduction to these resources.

This course provided an amazing overview of 20th-century American history. It traced the rhetoric used by politicians and activists to advocate for their ideologies, as well as the ways those ideologies changed.
Learned about 20th century american history, and how to use the plentiful library resources at Yale when looking at topics in American history.
I think an understanding of party realignment theought the century was an excellent way to track and incriproate lots of material.
expanded my knowledge about 20th century political, economic, and social US history - different historical actors, movements, and eras
Some history
This course really helped me understand the footing and basis of a lot of American politics today.
Good overview of American history in the 20th century. Covers lots of big themes, helpful for understanding current American political system.

I learned how to work in the archives of Sterling and how to navigate the Congressional records. I also learned how to write a 12 page research paper and how to acknowledge the contradictory aspects of our history. I was surprised by how much I did not know about the American twentieth century that I learned in this class.
We learned about presidential politics and grassroots movements throughout the twentieth century. We traced the progression of political thought and social movements throughout the century.

I gained a sound knowledge of 20th century US political history. I had not studied certain time periods, such as the New Conservative Era, very much in the past. A comprehensive study of the century allowed me to gain a more complete grasp of the development of US politics.
Good broad knowledge of the 20th century. I enjoyed the focus on popular culture instead of just straight political history. First slide was WJB election loss, last slide was 9/11.

I learned a lot about US history in the 20th century. I also learned how to do archival research at Yale, and also gained familiarity with library resources like Congressional Insights and Legislative insights.
20th century american history
I have learned a vast amount about United States 20th Century history. This course has given me insight into our modern political parties and social institutions have formed.

I learned so much about the 20th century that I had not already known. I went into the course thinking that I knew most of what was going to be taught, but Prof. Gage managed to organize the class in such a way that allowed us to go into certain topics in great depth and also trace key themes.

I gained a nuanced understanding of US history in the 20th century. In addition, I learned how to better analyze primary sources, search through books in the stacks, and sift through the congressional record.
I got a very good sense of major events that shaped 20th century America, and I now feel like I better understand trends in politics, foreign policy, and society that led to where we are today.
General understanding of 20th century American history, arcs of political movements, parties, and individuals, as well as introduction to archival research in SML and Beinecke
Clear understanding of political trends throughout the 20th century and their implications for today
I learned how to better understand learning and parsing history.
I gained a lot of knowledge about 20th Century American history and learned how to utilize Yale Library resources.
This course provides a general history of the US in the 20th century, and applies it to the modern world. It helped me compare todays politics to the past.
A broad and thorough knowledge of American History.
A more in depth run of American history throughout the 1900s as well as an exposure to the different libraries at Yale.
I learned how to properly use Yale's library system in writing essays, along with in-depth knowledge about American social trends throughout the 1900s
Reading and discussing 20th century politics questions from a history perspective
I gained a broad understanding of 20th century American political history. I also worked on historical research skills (working in archives, accessing databases, writing papers).

I learned so much about all of the historical resources that Yale has to offer - definitely a highlight of the class. Each of the assignments gave me the opportunity to familiarize myself with the archives or the libraries.
The papers in this class are targeted at developing new skills. I learned how to research in the Beinecke, the Stacks, and the Congressional Record.
heavy lecture style, heavy amount of reading, but resources like lecture slides felt inaccessible. Attending the lectures (which is not always possible) was too essential to succeed in the class.

Really did not like the lack of lecture sides posted. This really put me in a tough position for studying for the final because I tend to just listen during lecture and take sparse notes, and use the slides to review. This detail of the class really did not set me up for success.

Strengths - good Professor
Weakness - Went very fast, notes were hard to take from the speed, the readings were not always discussed in either section or lecture which was frustrating because we had to read about 3 hours of material every week
Lectures were very engaging and the assignments were cool because they forced you to take advantage of different library resources.

The subject matter was really interesting and Beverly Gage is an impressive historian who is passionate about her work (a coming biography on J. Edgar Hoover). My TA Salon Bhaman was great at engaging in deeper analysis of the material. Unfortunately, the lectures almost always went overtime, with the beginning being long winded and the end being super rushed. I felt that the decades of the 80s and 90s were overlooked, whereas there was way too much time spent on the New Deal.
The lectures are phenomenally delivered. I wish the lecture slides were posted on canvas, however. Regardless, the class was engaging and interesting.
Loved the lectures!! They were so engaging, and I appreciated the assignments as well! Overall. The class is very strong!

I felt that some of the reading assignments were excessive. I sometimes felt compelled to skim readings rather than really engage in them, and I sometimes felt that this took away from learning interesting details. 

The lectures were a good balance of specific information and broader structure, and provided a good grounding for the weekly readings.

Lectures were great, and the readings also paired together nicely. Professor Gage is really knowledgable and was very easy to understand. Her no laptop's policy is pretty outdated -- especially for people like me who have trouble keeping up with handwriting notes. Other than that great class.

The biggest strength of the class was Beverly Gage. She is the best lecturer I have had at Yale (I am a STEM student, so I guess that's not a terribly high bar to meet but still) and was an absolute delight during lectures. Her obsession with Hoover was endearing and she was incredibly open and helpful during office hours as well. The weakness of this class is the workload. I was in the WR section and had to do weekly reading responses, three writing assignments, a 15 page final paper, a midterm AND a final. Perhaps those in the WR section could do away with having to do a final, instead having to do longer writing assignments throughout the term and a slightly longer final paper. Another weakness of the class was its (lack of) clarity regarding assignments. The expectations for each assignment varied greatly between teaching assistants and there was no rubric to guarantee standardisation across sections which proved to be problematic when looking at the grade distributions.
MY TA FUCKING SUCKS

Strengths: jam-packed, interesting lectures; diversity of material
Weaknesses: not enough focus on important social issues such as feminism or LGBTQ rights; order and organization of lectures was quite confusing; lectures far too rushed at the end of each class

Strengths: Professor Gage is one of the best history lecturers I've had at Yale. the course is so well organized and excitingly taught. the readings were very engaging and not unnecessarily long.

Weaknesses: the essay assignments were at-times frustrating. very big disparity in how different TAs graded.
Strengths were lectures and selected readings.
Great readings, great lecturer.

I was a big fan of the writing assignments for this course. Working with primary documents isn't something I had the chance to do in the rest of my courses, and it really made the history come alive for me.

I loved the lectures; they were engaging and well-organized from day to day. I also really enjoyed how the papers were open-ended and I could choose to write about whatever I wanted to learn more about.

The course was very well taught and incredibly interesting. Professor Gage is a fantastic lecturer and taught all of the information very well. It was a little frustrating to have some of the lectures done by TFs, because they were not as well organized or as clear speakers as Professor Gage, which made the material covered in their lectures less accessible.
This was an amazing class. The readings were so engaging and Prof. Gage is an incredible lecture, although sometimes she had to rush the end of her lecture to get through all the content

The strength of  this course was how it forced students to engage with the library resources and to understand a general timeline of 20th century history. The weakness was that it mostly focused on one particular perspective of history, specifically it was very political party/ideology oriented and skipped some key events of the 20th century such as the Korean War or the Suffrage movement.

Professor Gage was engaging and informative. She was a great lecturer and included the right amount of material. The short essays allowed us to utilize the great resources here at Yale and section was helpful in understanding the material.
Very well structured class. Progresses as history progresses.
I think one thing the course could work on was focusing too much on certain topics and not mentioning others at all.
I thought it was a very strong course overall and not sure I would change or improve it just because it is exactly what it is described as and what I signed up for.

The strength of this class is the lectures, which were invariable interesting. The writing assignments were also really cool, because they were focused in structure (e.g. analyzing any document from a specified set of primary source collections) but open-ended in topic. The workload was above-average -- the weekly reading responses were a lot.

I think that the assignments and the intention behind the assignments are a great strength of the course, as it allowed for students to utilize a variety of sources, while giving us the freedom to research topics we were most interested in.

The lectures are super engaging--often feels like watching a cool documentary. The reading ranges, with the primary sources often being quite exciting and the secondary stuff not so much. My section was not particularly engaging or enjoyable, but I think that depends on the TF.
The TAs and Professor are fantastic. Great structure, wish it was a seminar
Professor Gage is a genius and created an incredible syllabus for this course. Section was not great, but that varies TF to TF, so your mileage may vary.

I think one thing that could be changed is that the midterm fell more in the middle of the semester so that there isn't so much material just on the final. The 1960s are complicated! The short writing assignments were pretty easy, though sometimes the TFs expected too much from 2-3 pages.
The course was well-taught. Beverly Gage is magical. Her lectures are captivating, charismatic and informative. I'm a total fan.

Covers many movements and trends. Sometimes this causes surface level discussion of deep topics, which is unavoidable in a survey course. Instead of focusing on main takeaways, sometimes the course devolves into throwing a bunch of events and dates out in lecture without focusing as much on analysis.

Weakness: There are just three, three page papers. They are not time-consuming, but it isn't clear exactly what they want from us. It was one-part historical analysis and one-part personal anecdote about our experience. Problem is, with just 2-3 pages, you can't do much of either.

Great course! Very solid, don't have any suggestions besides that I only wish that we had focused a little less on the inclusion of Yale into the historical narrative (would be interesting in smaller tidbits) and a little more on the nuances of social movements (talk about Malcolm X, maybe?).

I thought the assignments were very well thought out, and perfect for a first-year who is thinking about majoring in history (or really any other major). I say this as a junior. The midterm felt very rushed to complete in 50 minutes, maybe reduce it to 4 IDs and an essay instead of 5 IDs! I also appreciated some of the teaching fellow lectures, however one of them was really not well organized. I think Professor Gage should vet the TF lectures before they are given. Also, some of the assigned chapters for the books were not released until the weekend before the section on that reading. The assigned chapters need to be released on the syllabus for the course.

I really really like this class! It was definitely fast paced, but I appreciated how Professor Gage and the TAs focused more on themes and trends than specific events and dates. The assignments were really fun and interesting. I like how we could choose to write about whatever topic we liked. I appreciated having the workshops to help with the assignments. I think that maybe the only thing I would change is the final exam. I think it would have been better and more interesting to have a final paper instead. It would have helped be synthesize the material more effectively.
The course is taught well. I would like to see every lecture be made by professor Gage as opposed to some teaching fellows.

The course is structured very well overall. Prof. Gage does a great job fitting a lot of information into 50-minute segments. It would be nice if her lecture slides were on Canvas for test review, and for people like me who have to miss a few classes over the course of the semester for athletics-related travelling. At times the information presented in the course also felt slightly biased towards a certain set of political views, more so regarding the TA guest lectures than Prof. Gage's lectures. Still a very worthwhile experience, though.

Gage is a great professor and so knowledgeable. Lectures were great and fun to go to. However the class really did feel like a survey. Although this is inevitable given the broad scope of the class, I did not always feel like we were digging as deep as one should in a normal Yale course. This may have been due to a lack of engagement with section where these opportunities would have been more clear.

I didn't have a great TF/section experience. Although my TF was enthusiastic and knowledgeable, he treated section more as a chance to lecture and teach, than as a chance for students to discuss the readings and lectures in greater depth.

Of course, this is a lecture covering a huge span of time so naturally not everything can get covered, but I felt like some topics got heavy coverage while other events that were significant to American history (ex: the Korean war, the US's reaction to the Bosnian war) were completely glossed over. I would have preferred maybe a more even distribution of coverage on different events in American history.
The course can be a bit challenging in terms of pace for students who have never taken American History before

The strengths lie in the syllabus and Professor Gages lectures. She is really good at staying neutral on controversial issues and is drivers engaging talks. The major weakness is in the fact that I dont think we covered enough political history and spent a bit too much time on social movements. For example, I think we could have spent more time on the Vietnam War and less on talking about more minor social movements. The guest lectures by the TAs were also really poor.
Please post the lecture slides
I really enjoyed the lectures in this course, and I liked the Professor.

The strength of this course is its organization. Lectures are very clearly structured and it is easy to determine what specific topics and skills are supposed to be learned throughout the course. The weakness of the course are the contents of some the readings. Usually there was 1 reading per week that seemed somewhat misplaced from the content of the surrounding lectures.

Professor Gage is a very engaging lecturer and was able to cover lots of material in a way that felt accessible and well-structured. More clarity in some of the writing assignments could be helpful as there were times when I wasn't totally sure how best to approach such short assignments.
I thought the lectures were great and were very engaging.
The readings provided for this course were definitely a strength.

The strengths of this class, aside from the material and the lecturer which were both strengths, were the unorthodox essay prompts that forces students to use parts of campus' facilities and archives we otherwise probably never would've used, but now know how to use in the future. The biggest weakness was the ban of computers in section but making all the readings online.

This was the best lecture I have been to at Yale. The pace is consistent and the slideshows are easy to follow and very interesting. Im not sure I was a fan of the type of writing assignments we had, as I am typically in favor of the standard analytic essay. It was often unclear what was expected from our short papers, and as a result the grading at times felt unfair.

The main strength of the course was Prof. Gages lectures - they were very engaging and I liked the no-laptop policy. I also enjoyed our sections discussions. The courses weakness was in some of the TFs guest lectures - sometimes they went too fast and skimmed over really interesting topics (especially feminism and gay rights).
I thought the readings were all very engaging and lectures were fantastic. Professor Gage was very passionate and extremely knowledgable.

I thought the lectures were engaging and fun, but didnt feel they went in depth covering the the political changes throughout the 20th century. I thought these would be covered in section, but we rarely discussed the actual political shifts I thought we would cover.

I found the lecture to be very engaging, and Professor Gage had a very clear way of explaining historical events and their place in relation to broader themes. I also found that the readings were generally relevant and made for a fruitful discussion in section, though they were at times long and difficult to grasp.

Strengths: short papers are a great way to engage, loved the assignment of going to manuscripts and archives so I was less afraid of using that resource, really enjoyed the lectures.

Weakness: When you have a course that covers so much material, it is helpful if the TA's put together a list of terms at the end to make it easier to study. The instructors kept saying that the IDs on the midterm and final would be "pretty obvious", but they were actually quite a bit more obscure than implied.

The course focused a lot on domestic policy, so it perhaps could have focused more on foreign policy as well.  Additionally, some of the topics felt overly rushed and pointless because the course was trying to cover so much.

The lectures were fantasticProf. Gage is very engaging, and she has such a deep knowledge of the material. The readings were also very well-selected. The short assignmentsthree 2-3 page paperscould have been improved. They felt a bit like hand-holding to me (you had to take a selfie while doing research in the stacks as part of one of them), and I think they could have been more fulfilling. Perhaps it could have been a requirement that they all concern the same subject? In some ways, it would have been easier if they had been thesis-driven because the expectations for these assignments were a bit unclear.

Strengths: Beverly Gage!!! she's such an engaging lecturer and truly an expert in her field. I was always so amazed how she was able to clarify larger themes among specific historical examples while at the same time, crafting an overarching narrative that connected the themes/specifics/etc. together in a way that wasn't dogmatic. 
Weaknesses: the tests. My goodness, please please please post the slides next time. I went to every single lecture, took pretty meticulous notes, and attended section, but when it came time to take the tests, I was SO lost. I had such a hard time studying for them because there was no outline or timeline or ID list.
Very interesting class.
The breadth was a strength, especially for international students. The writing assignments also made me much better at research skills.

-well-organized and engaging lectures but sometimes goes too fast
-papers were interesting to write but different from the midterm and final
If you're into american history then sure, but I did not love it.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Great way to learn about American history from the 20th century. If you have any interest in U.S. history I highly recommend this course!
Depends pretty much solely on the TF you get assigned. Lecture was very interesting though!

I would recommend this course to someone learning to get an introduction to American politics. Professor Gage gives a good (though biased) introduction to the 1900s and ties it into politics today. However, the course does at times feel like APUSH.
Yes, it was interesting and very manageable!
A great class with a great lecturer. Definitely recommend.
Take this class if you want to go deeper in your studies in American history.
I would recommend the class to a student who doesn't know much about politics in the 20th century and would like to take a survey course on it.
Absolutely! This course provides a very clear overview of an important part of American history, and does so in a thoughtful, engaging way.
Yes, the course was very useful because I think we learned lots of basic historical-political information that most people living in the US should study ti understand the current political situation.

Highly recommend. For American history people this course will be lots of review, but for anyone seeking a broad and easy to digest perspective of the American 20th century you really cannot beat this class. A perfect 5th class.

This was a fine class. I would recommend it to someone who is interested in learning more about the subject material but I would try to shop around to see what TA suits your learning style the best because that really affects what you take away from the course.
yes
Yes, I would.

Yes, I would recommend this course to other students who want to learn a lot about 20th Century American history. For anyone seeking an overview, this is great. Do not take this course, however, if you want to delve into the specifics of certain social movements that evolved throughout the 20th century.
I would, but I would warn them about the essays. They are kind of annoyingly short and provide very little opportunity to answer all of the questions that the TAs want to have answered.
Yes! Great history class and its very important to better understand the good & bad of our countrys past.
yes!

If you've taken APUSH in high school, I wouldn't recommend this course. The first 60-70% of the class is a strict subset of APUSH material. On the other hand, the latter 30-40% is really interesting and was mostly new to me. It provided really valuable context to modern politics, but this wasn't enough to offset the mediocre beginning content. I'd really like to see a version of this course that only covers post-WWII history; I think that would maximize the value of the course for me.
Yes, especially for non-History majors. It's a low-stakes course that is still rewarding and interesting.

Yes - if you are looking for a comprehensive overview of 20th century American history, especially if your high school didn't cover it completely, this is a great course, and Professor Gage is a fantastic lecturer.
Yes!! Absolutely take it. You will learn so much and become a more informed citizen.

I definitely would. It was very interesting history, with an intensive focus on the history of American politics. Because these topics are often not taught, it is a good class to inform people on the history of politics that manifest itself in today's political environment.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is very useful for a knowledge of history and not an unfair amount of work.
Most definitely. A good introduction into US history.
Absolutely. Professor is incredible and chooses great TFs that are a great extension of the professor.
I would if they would like to learn more about American history and politics.

definitely. I think the professor is really great and it goes over all the major trends and topics in US history that i believe everyone interested in learning about American history and how we got to where we are today should learn about.
Yes!
If you're interested in American politics or history, I would. It's a very well-taught, interesting class. It's definitely not a gut, but the workload isn't too bad.
Yes! The lectures are truly wonderful. Professor Gage rocks. It's a very comprehensive overview of the 20th Century and I feel I learned an enormous amount.
Yes! Take it if you can or are interested in the topic. Awesome lectures, great discussion. Doesn't get better than this at Yale!
Yes! Take everything you can with Professor Gage!
I think this is a great intro American history lecture and Professor Gage has well-organized lectures. It's also a super easy WR credit.
yes

I would totally recommend the American Century to another student, especially if they want to learn about more recent American history in a more nuanced way than high school APUSH. It was my ideal survey class for history. But then again, I also really like survey classes because I prefer to have a general understanding of a lot of things rather than an in-depth understanding of something super narrow in scope. I liked how we were able to get up to the year 2000; the course started with Populism in the 1900s and ended with the year some of us were born. The grading is also not bad. As long as you do the readings, which are totally manageable, and go to the lecture, you'll be fine. Be warned that Prof Gage does not post her lecture slides on Canvas. You must go to the lecture, but that won't be a problem because you'll enjoy going. Also, no laptops in lecture. I think I actually took better notes because I didn't write down everything she said word-for-word, which forced me to think and summarize the most important things when writing things down.

Good survey history class of major political trends and social movements of the 20th century. Sometimes seemed to focus too much on social movements. Superficial handling of some topics due to time constraints sometimes came off as biased.
Absolutely. The reading list is good and Gage is a great lecturer. Her lectures are structured really well to provoke structured thoughts but also provide lots of information.

Yes, absolutely take if you want to think more in particular about the history of political parties and of liberalism and conservatism more generally, the changing relationship between the American people and the state, and the role of the US in the world. The primary readings are really cool for this course. Don't expect to have your mind blown, but expect to learn a lot and understand the US in the 20th century a lot better. Finally, if you are specifically looking for in depth analysis of US social movements, this isn't the course for you  while they are definitely included, this course is primarily focused in high politics.

I learned a ton about 20th century American history, and the assignments are really not very difficult. You still have to do work for the class, but it isn't intellectually challenging in the way writing a research paper would be. If you want a good overview of the American Century with two engaging lectures each week, I highly recommend the course.

I loved this class! I took it as a STEM major to fulfill my HU requirement and found that it was just the right amount of work. It wasn't a gut, but it wasn't overwhelming either. I found this class to be super engaging and the content was really interesting and relevant. I had a great section and we had really fascinating discussions! I thought that the assignments were fun and not too high-stakes. If you're interested in America at all, then definitely take this class. It's mostly information that I felt I should've already known and Professor Gage is a great lecturer!
I would wholeheartedly recommend this class to other students. It was an engaging and well taught history lecture.
I'd definitely recommend this course to any student who wishes to gain an understanding of today's America by learning about the America of the prior century.
Gage is a great professor to take a class with and the course does do a great job of overviewing the 20th century. However the survey does feel a bit shallow at time.

This is a great course to take, particularly for folks less used to Humanities & writing intensive social science courses. It covered topics that are very relevant and did so in a clear and interesting way. It was perhaps less mind-blowing than some other history classes I've taken as a history major, but is overall a really solid course I enjoyed

Professor Gage is a really great lecturer, seriously. She's incredibly engaging and her lectures are really well-structured. This class is really interesting if you want to learn more about the US in the 20th century. Overall, I'd definitely recommend this class if you're interested in getting a survey of American history.
Its a great course - Professor Gage is a very good professor. Section with the TAs is also good. Take it :)
Yes, I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking to study social movements or someone who wants a background in US history if they dont already have one.
Yes. As someone already with a decent background in American History, I learned so much from Professor Gage's lectures

Yes I would recommend this course to another student because it is all valuable information about American history. A lot of our history has shaped the issues we still have today in society that are valuable issues to understand in politics, the economy, and the social inter workings of American society.

Yes--I think this course was a well-explained history and analysis of the twentieth century. Professor Gage was very engaging, and she focused a lot on longer trajectories of history than other classes I have taken.
I would recommend this class, its interesting content and the professor presents the material in a captivating way.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in learning more about American history from multiple perspectives beyond which those that are typically taught in a high school setting.

Definitely. This course does a great job teaching the history of America in the 20th century and gives a great standard look into the history department at Yale, how it works, how it can work in terms of essay writing, and all of its amenities.
Yes, if youre interested in a broad overview of 20th century American history focused on politics and social movements.
Absolutely!

If you already took AP US history and feel you took a lot from this class, then I would reconsider taking this. A lot of what is covered in this class goes over the exact same things in the Apush curriculum. Of course, the lectures and readings add more nuance to whats learned, but whether this added complexity is worth taking a whole class for is debatable.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I think it gives an invaluable understanding of the foundations for present-day American politics, and it forced me to consider themes such as party polarization and the structure of movements in both a historical and contemporary context. The class also acquainted us with various resources at Yale, including the archives, the stacks, and databases, which I think will be useful going forward in my next few years here.

I would certainly recommend this class. As a junior majoring in a humanities field, I found this class very interesting and highly enjoyable. Professor Gage is an engaging lecturer with deep knowledge of the subject -- more than enough to stretch my background knowledge of 20th-century American history. The writing assignments were well-constructed: a good review for some and (I imagine) a good introduction for others to archival and secondary research. This was my first history course at Yale, and I very much enjoyed it.

yes! I think we have a tendency to throw around "progressive" "conservative" and "liberal", but this classes teaches you the origins of this movements in a way that's really helpful. This classes included a lot of things that APUS neglects (black panther party, vietnam)

Yes, if you want an introduction to 20th century American history.  But this class does have way above average workload for a history lecture, including weekly reading responses which felt really quite useless.

YesProf. Gage is an expert in US history and this is a unique opportunity to learn about US-history in a well-organized, cohesive way. Someone told me at the beginning, "you can just read a texbook," but I learned so much more from a semester listening to Prof. Gage's lectures. Particularly if you're interested in political rhetoric, or political movements, or the way that political change occurs, this is the class for you.
Yes! If you're interested in learning about 20th century history of the US, and to understand the historical references that people talk about when discussing today's politics.

Yes! Great and easy and engaging lecture. The assignments really help you learn and are fun. I'd say take it if you're interested in breadth and don't have broad familiarity with US history; take it also if you do have a good grasp on US history, but maybe as a fifth class.

yes. if you're interested in US history, this course gives a very clear breakdown of the 20th century. whether you're a history major or not, this course is important to take in order to learn about how the 20th century impacts our lives today.
